name: 2,3-o-isopropylidene-l-threitol
Reason: The basic unit for comparison could be ethylene glycol, which has a melting point of about -13 C. The isopropylidene group (+CH2)2 connecting two oxygen atoms can increase the melting point due to steric hindrance and the potential for intramolecular hydrogen bonding, thus increasing the melting point by approximately +30 degrees Celsius. Each hydroxyl group typically contributes to an increase in the melting point because of intermolecular hydrogen bonding. However, intramolecular hydrogen bonding within the constrained ring may reduce the extent of intermolecular bonding. Thus, the effect of hydroxyl at this situation would be reduced to around +10 degrees Celsius per hydroxyl group. There are two hydroxyl groups not involved in the isopropylidene acetal, thus totaling an additional +20 degrees Celsius. Overall addition to the base ethylene glycol melting point would be +50 degrees Celsius, leading to a predicted melting point of approximately 37 C.
